utterances: But go ahead.
So the question is why do we see this clustering.
If the country as a whole is fairly evenly divided political, why do we see these concentrations of red and blue?
Now, one theory is that it's because of feedback effects.
If you live in an area that is conservative to begin with, over time, you become conservative yourself.
So that's...
You hear lots of conservative views around you, in other words.
The researchers describe their work in the journal Science.
Gerry Wright studies antibiotic resistance at McMaster University in Ontario.
He says when he read this paper his first thought was that he wished he'd done the experiment.
(SOUNDBITE OF TV SHOW, ""FACE THE NATION"")
Beaver's head of college counseling, Peter Gow, agrees.
The whole system is like an evil machine thats consuming kids, he says.
Our school has defanged it, but only as much as any one school can.
Tovia Smith, NPR News.
It's MORNING EDITION from NPR News.
Good morning.
I'm Steve Inskeep.
Days after a tropical cyclone, it appears that American aid is not reaching Myanmar.
The White House says a U.S.
disaster recovery team is still waiting on visas.
And U.S.
Navy ships in the region have not been allowed into port.
Myanmar's military government is allowing some emergency supplies from other sources, and military helicopters are flying over the low-lying river delta wrecked by the storm.
The helicopters are said to be dropping food and drinking water to survivors.
We're going to learn more now from Souheil Reich, director of Doctors Without Borders, the mission in Yangon, Myanmar's major city.
And what have the last few days been like for you, sir?
They've been very, very difficult for us, because we are preparing our intervention in the south of Yangon, where approximately one million people could have been affected by this cyclone.
So we are working to try to gather drugs and supplies.
Just trying to get supplies.
Now, as you are trying to marshal those supplies, have you or members of Doctors Without Borders been out into the affected area and sent back reports of what's happening now?
The problem is the access.
Most of the affected areas are flooded.
We have access in some places which are two hours from here or from Yangon.
What we saw in these villages, 80 percent of the villages were destroyed.
Do you think that the government has the capacity to handle this disaster?
They are trying to do some things, but it's definitely not enough.
They don't have enough resources to respond to this emergency.
And that's why we're discussing with them to be able to ship some goods in Myanmar.
You want to get some goods and some drugs from outside the country into the country?
Yes.
Yes.
I was discussing today with one of the ministers, basically allow us to send a plane with 40 drums of water supply, drugs and shelter materials in the country.
Where are you going to get it from?
We're going to get it from Switzerland.
From Switzerland?
That raises another question.
We're being told that American aid is not being allowed into the country.
Of course, the United States has been very, very critical of Myanmar's military government.
Has the government been more welcoming of aid from other sources, and if so, what sources?
What can I say?
I think the main issue is to allow the foreigners to come in the country.
But I'm sure that with the pressure and with the needs, they will have to accept more, I would say, experts and specialists in various sectors to support them.
Is the government giving reasons not to admit foreigners, additional foreigners into the country?
First of all, they consider that they have enough capacity - I would say human resources capacity in the country.
Oh, they've said they have enough capacity?
In terms of human resources, but they are - as I say, they are welcoming any goods from outside.
They're saying send materials but don't bother to send people.
Yes.
Exactly.
And it sounds like you don't think that's enough.
For MSF it's not enough.
As I say, the risk of epidemics is quite high and that's why we need public health specialists and water and sanitation specialists.
Souheil Reich directs Doctors Without Borders, the mission in Myanmar.
He spoke with us from Yangon, the largest city in that country.
And you can find photos of the Myanmar cyclone and its impact at npr.org.
Now let's report on food of a different kind - antibiotics, food for bacteria.
That takes a little explaining because antibiotics are supposed to kill bacteria.
But scientists were surprised to find that some germs actually love the stuff, they eat it.
And it turns out these bacteria are as common as dirt, which is where they live.
Here's NPR's Nell Greenfieldboyce.
Gautam Dantas of Harvard Medical School in Boston says he and his colleagues didn't have to travel far to make this scientific discovery.
There's soil everywhere.
So we just walked up to, you know, one of the public gardens right outside Fenway Park and took a scoop of the soil.

They took the bacteria from this dirt, then they put the microbes in a situation where they would not only have to survive in the presence of an antibiotic; the germs would actually have to use the antibiotic as food in order to live.
Dantas figured they wouldn't be able to do it and they'd die.
And so we were quite surprised that those couple antibiotics that we tested initially gave large amounts of bacterial growth.
The researchers thought, hmm, what's going on?
So they went out and got dirt from about a dozen places.
Like a pristine forest, a farm, a city park.
And they did the same tests with additional antibiotics - 18 in all.
And in no case did we find an antibiotic that was not eaten by a bacteria.
It turns out that many different soil bacteria - hundreds - could live on an antibiotic diet.
What's more, the scientists discovered something else.
If a bug could happily eat one antibiotic, it was also likely to survive when exposed to others.
On average they were resistant to 17 out of the 18 antibiotics at concentrations used in the clinic.
Which is, at least in our mind, that was mind-blowing.
Now, this study didn't look at bacteria that cause disease in people, but Dontez is a little troubled by the idea that genes for this kind of drug resistance are just out there in the dirt.
Since some soil bacteria are related to human and animal germs, he worries that they could pass on their genes for drug resistance.
Now, Fred Fielding says - Fred Fielding is the White House counsel, Alex - and Fred Fielding says, you know what?
We're looking for these e-mails.

It's not that we're trying to stonewall - and that's of course the allegation that's been coming from the likes of Chuck Schumer, the senator from New York - and it was not the case that we're lying - which is the allegation coming from Senator Leahy of Vermont - and we are trying to be fair - which is the allegation coming from Senator Specter, Republican of Pennsylvania, who says that there is not here a fair and clear standard.
So Fred Fielding says yes, we are trying to be fair.
We're looking for these e-mails and our offer still stands.
We'll let you interview these folks personally but not under oath and with no transcripts.
Okay.
Well, this will settle everything, make everyone feel better.
Congress is back next week in full, Senate and the House, going to meet to agree on the legislation they've already passed to pay for the Iraq war and set a date for American troops to get out of it.
What do you expect?
Well, I expect that what you'll get is no hard deadline, at least initially.

Some of the Democrats are saying, you know what, in the House the reason we voted, the reason that the people on the left side of the political spectrum went along with Nancy Pelosi is because we expect a deadline in this.
So they may have to try to hold that in the House.
The Senate will try to say, no, let's not put in the deadline because that gives the president a real strong reason to say this is the reason he's vetoing.
Let's just go with benchmarks.
In either case, though, the White House says they're going to veto it.

So what you get is Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid saying that if he vetoes this - and this is the game of big bluff, big poker, Alex - if he vetoes it, then I'm going to put up a bill that calls for an immediate withdrawal and raises the stakes in the game.
Okay.
One big item coming next week I think we'll all be looking for on Tuesday - the attorney general is finally going to appear before the Senate Judiciary Committee, isn't he?
Yeah.
Well, you know, it's so strange.
Over the last few weeks, we haven't seen Alberto - much of Alberto Gonzales.
And according to all the reports, over the last few weeks he's doing several hours a day of prep for this meeting up on Capitol Hill, this interview, and he hasn't been doing all that well.
They have people like Ed Gillespie, the former chair of the Republican National Committee, over at Justice in private chambers trying to work with him.
But boy, everything's on the table.
All the marbles are for play for Gonzales because it just doesn't look good for him at this point politically, Alex.
We'll have something to talk about next Friday, Juan?
Indeed.
